PREFACE. 


Tltrgot,  tlie  confessor  of  Saint  Margaret,  relates,  that  immediately  after  her  marriage 
with  Malcolm  III.,  the  Queen,  in  that  place  where  the  nuptials  were  celebrated,  as  a 
lasting  memorial  of  her  name  and  her  piety,  founded  a  church,  which  sho  dedicated 
to  the  Holy  Trinity,  and  enriched  with  numerous  ornaments,  vessels  of  solid  gold, 
and  an  inestimable  crucifix,  formed  of  gold,  silver  and  precious  stones.' 

This  passage,  of  the  best  authority,  seems  partly  to  countenance  the  narrative 
of  Boece,  who,  after  detailing  the  storm  which  drove  the  fleet  with  the  Saxon  Princes 
into  the  Firth  of  Forth,  and  their  sheltering  in  the  road  still  called  Saint  Margarefs 
Hope,-  gives  his  usual  romantic  colouriug  to  the  incident.  Malcolm,  who  then 
resided  at  Dunfermlin,  sent  envoys  to  enquire  of  what  lineage  and  country  the  strangers 
were, — 

Sed  vos  qui  tandem,  quibus  aut  venistis  ab  oris, 

Quove  tenetis  iter  ? 
And  having  leamed  that  they  were  of  the  line  of  the  Confessor,  his  benefactor, 
received  them  with  courtly  honour,  and  in  a  few  days  proposed  marriage  to  the  sister 
of  the  Saxon  prince. 

This  auspicious  marriage  took  place  certainly  not  later  than  the  year  1070  ;» 

'  "  I  can  speak  more  confidently  of  these,  as  I  was  And  all  the  weddrys  in  thaire  feyre 

appointed  by  the  Queen  to  take  charge  of  them,  and  Wes  to  thare  purpose  all  contrayre, 

long  had  them  in  my  custody." —  Vita  Maryarete  apud  That  of  fors,  as  wynd  thame  movyd, 

BoUinJum  et  Piiikerton.     See  also  Fordun.  Come  in  the  fyrth  than  thame  behowyd, 

2  Wyntoun  gives  the  account  of  the  Saxon  princes  And  in  Saynt  Margretis  Hope  be-lyve 

Ijeing  driven  by  stress  of  weather  into  the  Fiith : Of  propyre  nede  than  till  arry ve. 

'•  Qulien  this  Edgare  Ethlyng,  On  this  manere  Saynt  Margret 

That  of  lawch  suld  have  bene  k)-ng,  In-til  the  kynryk  apon  thret 

The  kynryk  saw  dystrowblyd  swa,  Come  of  hapnyng  in  Scotland, 

Of  cownsale  wyth  hys  systrys  twa,  Quhen  Malcolme  in  it  wes  kyng  ryngnand."

For  to  pas  agayne  thowcht  he  princes  landed  was  called  Sinus  S.  Margarele  .■  and

X  PREFACE. 

and  if  it  was  celebrated  at  Dunfermlin,  we  must  suppose  that  at  that  early  period  it 
was  already  a  Royal  residence.'  It  probably  continued  to  be  so  during  the  reign  of 
Malcolm,  for  otlierwise  the  Queen^s  confessor  and  constant  attendant  could  not  have 
had  the  personal  custody  of  the  treasures  of  the  new  church. 

The  situation  of  Dunfermlin,  within  an  easy  distance  of  the  prineipal  strengths 
of  Scotland,  and  protected  from  Southern  invasion  by  the  Scoticater,  is  likely  enough 
to  have  marked  it  out  as  a  suitable  residence  of  the  Court ;  and  the  local  tradition 
which  connects  a  very  ancient  tower  in  the  grounds  of  Pittencriefi',  with  the  name  of 
Malcohn  Canmore,  may  perhaps  point  to  the  rude  dwelHng  of  Royalty  before  the 
new  convent,  with  the  pleasant  site  which  marks  all  the  houses  of  the  Benedictines, 
and  the  comparative  luxury  which  churchmen  first  knew  to  throw  around  their 
dwelhngs,  allured  the  Sovereign  to  become  an  inmate  of  the  cloister. 

Dunfermlin  continued  for  many  generations  peculiarly  a  Royal  House.  Its 
early  benefactors  were  all  Kings  ;  and  in  imitatiou  of  its  saintly  founder,  the  succeed- 
ing  Princes  of  the  Royal  Family  of  Scotland  for  the  most  part  ehose  it  as  their  place 
of  burial. 

Before  the  rwde  awtare  wyth  honowre 

Scho  wes  layd  in  haly  sepulture. 

Thare  hyre  lord  wes  layd  alsua, 

And  wyth  thame  hyre  sownnis  twa, 

Edwarde  the  first  aud  Etlielred. 

Saynt  Margretis  body  a  hundyr  yhere 

Lay  befor  the  rwd  awtere, 

Into  the  kyrk  of  Dwnfermlyne  ; 

Bot  scho  wes  translatyd  syne 

Into  the  qwere  quhare  scho  now  lyis. 

Her  spyrit  intil  paradys. 

And  of  that  translatyowne, 

Made  wyth  weneratiowne, 

The  fest  yliit  is  haldyne  ay 

Befor  mydsumyr  the  fyft  day.^

PREFACE.  xi 

Who  were  the  first  oecupants  of  the  Abbey,  we  do  not  find.  It  has  been  gene- 
rally  stated  that  the  house  was  only  a  Priory  until  the  time  of  David, — an  opinion 
which  seems  to  have  no  other  foundation  than  the  occurrence  of  a  Peter,  Prior  of 
Dunfermlin,  among  the  ambassadors  to  England  in  1120.'  It  cannct  now  be  neces- 
sary,  even  in  Scotland,  to  remark,  that  the  existenee  of  a  Prior  does  not  preclude  the 
existence  of  an  Abbot.  David  I.  appears  to  have  remodelled  the  original  foundation, 
and  to  have  placed  in  it  an  Abbot  and  twelve  monks  from  Canterbury.^  The  Church, 
as  completed  or  restored  by  him,  was  dedicated  in  1150.^ 

David's  first  Abbot  was  Geofiry,  formerly  Prior  of  Canterbury,  tir  religionis 
eximie.  He  was  ordained  by  Bishop  Robert  of  Saint  Andrews  in  1128,''  died  in 
1154,  and  was  succeeded  by  his  nephew  of  the  same  name.° 

Galfridus  the  second  died  in  1178.'' 

Archibald,  or  Erkenbald,  was  the  uext  Abbot.  It  would  appear  that  the  use 
of  the  initial  letter  only  of  his  uame  in  instruments,  has  produced  the  mistake  of 
giving  Alanus  as  the  name  of  the  Abbot  in  his  time.'     Archibald  died  in  1198." 

Robert  de  Berewick  was  his  successor,^  who  was  deposed,  probably  for  irregu- 
larities,  by  the  Cardinal  Legate  John  de  Salerno.  a.d.  1202.'° 

Patrick,  sub-prior  of  Durham,  was  chosen  to  succeed  him."  He  is  a  witness  in 
transactions  along  with  WilHani  de  Malvoisin,  Bishop  of  St.  Andrews,'-  aud  it  must 
have  been  during  his  incuuibencj'  that  that  lordly  prelate  is  said  to  have  levied  on 
the  Abbey  the  niulct  of  no  less  than  two  churches,  for  supplying  wine  too  scantily 
in  the  Bishop's  chamber,  when  visiting  Dunfermlin.'^ 

We  hear  of  no  other  Abbot  till  William  ;  and  all  we  have  recorded  of  him  is 
his  death  in  12-38.'^ 

■'  Galfridus  prior  ejusdem  domus  successit,"''  but  held  the  office  only  two  years. 
He  died  in  1240.'« 

His  successor  was  Robert,  a  monk  of  the  couvent,  of  the  local  sumanie  of  Kel- 
delecht, — probably  the  same  name  which,  after  passing  through  many  phases,  has

xii  PREFACE. 

settled  into  that  of  Kinloch.  In  his  time,  after  much  negotiation,  took  place  the 
soleran  translation  of  Queen  Margaret.  It  was  in  1250,  the  year  of  the  coronation 
of  Alexander  III ; — 

That  yhere  wyth  weneratyown 

Wes  made  the  translatyown 

Of  Saynt  Margret,  the  haly  qwene. 

A  fayre  myrakil  thare  wes  sene  : 

The  thryd  Alysandyre  bodyly, 

Thare  wes  wyth  a  gret  eumpany 

Of  erlys,  byschapys,  and  barownys, 

And  mony  famows  gret  persownys  ; 

Of  Saynt  Andrewys  thare  wes  be  name 

The  Byschope  Davy  of  Barnhanie  ; 

Robert  of  Kyldeleth  syne 

That  Abbot  wes  of  Dunfermlyne. 

Powere  had  thai  than  at  fuUe 

Grawntyd  be  the  Papys  bulle,' 

To  mak  that  translatyown  : 

And  that  to  do  thai  mad  thame  bowne, 

And  fayndyt  to  gere  the  body 

Translatyd  be  of  that  lady. 

Wyth  all  thare  powere  and  thare  slycht 

Her  body  to  rays  thai  had  na  mycht, 

Na  lyft  hyr  anys  owt  of  that  plas, 

Quhare  scho  that  tyme  lyand  was, 

For  all  thare  devotyownys, 

Prayeris  and  gret  orysownys, 

That  the  persownys  gadryd  there 

Dyd  on  devot  manere  ; 

Quliyll  fyrst  thai  tuk  wpe  the  body 

Of  hyr  lord  that  lay  thare-by,

PREFACE.  xiii 

And  barc  it  bene  into  the  quere. 

Lystly  syne  on  fayre  manere 

Hyr  cors  tliai  tuk  wp  and  bare  ben, 

And  thame  enteryd  togyddyr  tlien. 

Swa  trowyd  thai  all  than  gadryd  thare 

Quhat  honoure  til  hyr  lord  scho  bare. 

Swa,  this  myrakil  to  record 

Notis  gret  reverens  dwne  til  hyr  lord  ; 

As  seho  oysyd  in  hyr  lyf, 

Quhen  seho  wes  hys  spousyd  wyf. 
Of  this  solempne  translatyowne 

Befor  thare  is  mad  mentyown  ; 

Bot  thare  is  noucht  notyd  the  yhere, 

Na  this  myrakil  wryttyn  here, 

That  suld  noucht  have  bene  forghet 

For  the  honoure  of  Saynt  Margret.' 
Abbot  Robert  became  Chancellor  of  the  kingdom,  and  had  influence  enough  to  obtain 
from  tlie  Pope,  for  him  and  his  successors,  the  privilege  of  exercising  within  their 
Abbey  the  functions,  and  using  the  insignia  of  Bishops.  From  this  time  Dunfermhn 
becanie  a  mitred  Abbacy.^  Being  raixed  up  with  the  obscure  plot  of  Alan  of 
Durward,  in  the  early  part  of  the  reign  of  Alexander  III.,  Robert  rehnquished  both 
his  ofEce  of  state  and  his  Abbacy  in  1252,  and  retired  as  a  simple  nionk  into  the 
Abbey  of  Newbotle,  from  whence  he  again  emerged  to  become  Abbot  of  Melros  in 
1269  ;  which  office  he  held  for  three  years  till  his  death.^ 

John,  prior  of  the  Convent,  vir  mirce  mansuetudinis,  was  made  Abbot  in  1252. 
on  the  resignation  of  Robert.''  It  appears  that  Dunfermlin,  with  other  relic^ious 
houses  of  Scotland,  was  subjected  to  a  Papal  interdict  for  default  of  sums  it  had 
undertaken  to  pay  for  promoting  the  confirmation  of  Gamelin  the  new  Bishop  of  St. 
Andrews.  In  1256,  Abbot  John  set  out  for  Rome  to  negotiate  the  release  of  his 
House,  but  died  ou  the  road  at  Pontigny.' 

Matthew,  the  cellarer,  was  the  next  Abbot,^  who  was  dead  before  1270  ;  for  in 
that  year  we  find 

Simon,  Abbot  of  Duufermlin,  sent  with  the  Earl  of  Mar,  as  ambassadors  to  Encr- 


Wi/ntoun,  vii.  10.  o/State,  p.  13,)  who  calls  him  a  monk  of  Newbotle.

xiv  PREFACE. 

land,  for  the  recovery  of  the  King"3  Earldom  of  Huntingdon.'  He  was  deposed  in 
1275,  by  the  Legate  Baiamund,  and  must  have  deserved  his  sentence,  since  Fordun, 
who  was  no  admirer  of  Cardinals  or  Legates,  says  he  was  punished  "  ob  innatam 
animi  pertinaciam  et  intolerahihm  operum  proterviam."^ 

Ralph  de  Grenlaw,  tlie  sub-prior,  "  ifir  mansuetm  ac  pro^eidus,  ac  in  monastica 
disciplina  satis  exercitatusr  succeeded  in  the  Abbacy.  He  is  found  in  transactions 
recorded  in  the  Register,  in  1280  and  1284;  and  in  1291  he  did  homage  to  Edward 
in  person  at  Dunfermlin,  and  again  at  Berwick  in  1296.^ 

Hugh  is  said  to  have  been  Abbot  of  Dunfermlin  in  the  7th  year  of  Robert  L'' 

Robert  de  Crail  was  Abbot  in  1316,  when  Duncan  Earl  of  Fife  did  homage  to 
him  for  the  lands  of  Cluny,  held  of  the  Abbey  in  capite.^ 

Alexander  Ber  became  Abbot  in  1331.  He  held  the  ofBce  for  twenty-two 
years,  and  having  made  a  journey  to  Rome  to  solicit  a  grant  of  a  general  indul- 
gence,  he  and  his  whole  company  died  (apparently  of  the  plague)  in  Lombardy  on 
his  way  home  in  1353. 

The  Convent  elected^  in  his  room  John  Blak,  their  cellarer.  But  John  of 
Stramiglaw,  a  young  monk  of  the  Abbey,  then  studying  at  Paris,  hurried  to  Avig- 
non,  and  obtained  a  Papal  presentation  to  the  Abbacy,  which  Blak  did  not  think 
proper  to  resist,  but  accepted  from  his  rival  first  a  pension  and  afterwards  the  Priory 
of  Urchard  in  Moray,  a  cell  of  the  Abbey.'' — Here,  unluckily,  we  lose  our  faithful 
chronicler,  old  John  of  Fordun.  The  measured  terms  in  whieh  he  speaks  of  the 
juggle  by  which  John  of  Stramiglaw  obtained  the  Abbacy,  leave  the  Impression  that 
he  was  still  in  office  while  the  historian  was  writing,  and  therefore  not  to  be  lightly 
spoken  of.^

PREFACE.  XV 

John  de  Torry  is  tlic  next  Abbot  whose  name  wc  tiud  mentioned.  He  held 
the  office  on  the  4th  December  1404,'  and  we  find  liim  increasing  the  allowances  of 
his  monks,  on  the  statement  of  increased  doarness  of  clothing,  on  the  13th  June  1-K)9.'^ 

William  de  Sancto  Andrea  was  Abbot  of  Dmifermlin  in  1414  and  1419,''  of 
whoni  nothing  is  known  but  his  name. 

On  tlie  last  day  of  July  1437,''  we  find  Andrew  Abbot,  who  appears  in  many 
transaetions  till  the  month  of  January  1441.^ 

On  the  16th  day  of  December  1446",  Richard  de  Bothuel  appears  as  Abbot  of 
Dunfermlin,^  and  he  figures  in  numerous  transactions  of  the  Abbey  after  that  date, 
the  latest  of  which  recorded  is  of  the  4th  of  May  1468.'  He  was  dead  before  the 
4th  November  1472." 

It  is  to  the  occasion  of  the  vacaucy  by  his  death,  we  owe  a  notable  passage  of 
Bishop  Leslye  on  the  abuses  of  Court  patronage  :

ceissit  all  religious  and  godlye  myndis  and  deidis  ;  quhairwith  the  secularis  and

xvi  PREFACE. 

Henry  Creichtoun,  the  King's  Abbot,  held  the  oiKce  till  after  6th  May  1482. 

Adam  was  Abbot  from  1483,  till  20th  June  1490.' 

George  is  said  to  liave  been  Abbot  in  1496,^  and  was  Abbot,  4th  February  1499.^ 

Robert  Blacader  is  said  to  have  been  Abbot  of  Dunfermlin,  and  to  have  died  in 
liis  journey  to  Syria  in  1500.'' 

James  Stuart,  second  son  of  King  James  III.,  Duke  of  Ross  and  Archbishop 
of  St.  Andrews,  held  the  Abbacy  of  Dunfermlin  in  commendam  from  1502  till  his 
death  in  1504. 

His  successor  in  the  Abbacy  was  James  Beton,  tlien  Provost  of  Bothwell,  after- 
wards  Bishop,  Arohbishop  and  Primate,  who  held  it  until  promoted  to  the  Bishoprick 
of  Galloway  in  1508,  or  perhaps  till  the  return  from  Italy,  in  1510,  of  his  destined 
successor. 

This  was  Alexander  Stuart.  natural  son  of  King  James  IV.,  Archbishop  of  St. 
Andrews,  and  Legate  a  latere,  a  prince  whom  Erasmus,  not  in  mere  flattery,  cha- 
racterised  as  worthy  to  spring  of  a  king,  and  of  such  a  king  as  his  father.^  He  held 
the  Abbacy  in  commendam  till  his  death  at  the  field  of  Flodden,  151.3. 

The  Abbacy,  wth  other  great  benefices,  was  now  a  subject  of  fierce  contention 
between  the  family  of  Hepburn  and  Andrew  Forman,  Arehbishop  Legate, — a  dispute 
which  ranked  all  the  nobility  of  Scotland  with  one  or  other  of  the  parties.  James 
Hepburn  assumed  the  title  of  Abbot  in  1515,®  as  chosen  by  the  Convent.  The  Le- 
gate  held  a  prior  grant  from  the  Pope.  The  law  was  not  quite  clear  ;  but,  St  any 
rate,  it  was  not  heard  in  such  cases,  in  the  regency  of  Albany.  The  Regent  endea- 
voured  to  appease  the  factions  by  a  compromise,  in  1517;  and  the  Abbacy  of  Dun- 
fermlin  fell  to  the  share  of  the  Ai-chbishop,  while  James  Hepburn  had  the  Bishop- 
rick  of  Moray.     Andrew  Forman  was  buried  in  the  Abbey  Church  in  1522.' 

James  Beton,  Arehbishop  of  Glasgow,  who  succeeded  Forman  in  tJie  Primacy, 
was  his  successor  also  in  the  Abbac}'  of  Dunfermlin,  wliich  he  held  a  second  time 
in  commendam,  and  afterwards  styled  himself  mufructuarius,  or  administrator  fruc- 
tuum,  while  he  allowed  the  name  and  probably  devolved  the  duties  of  Abbot  on 
George  Dury. 

George  Dury,  Archdeacon  of  St.  Andrews,  styled  himself  Abbot  of  Dunfermlin 
in  1530,'  and  he  continued  to  take  the  title  of  Abbot  or  Commendator,  apparently 
subordinate  to  the  Archbishop,  during  the  life  of  the  latter.     After  the  Primate^s

PREFACE.  xvii 

death,  in  1539,  he  aeted  as  Abbot  or  commendator.  The  latest  deeds  of  the  Ancient 
Register  are  granted  by  him,  and  in  two  of  the  volumes  of  feu-charters,  he  is  the 
granter  down  to  the  year  1560,  when  he  went  to  France  ;  and  it  is  uncertain  if  lie 
ever  returned.' 

Robert  Pitcairne,  of  the  opposite  party,  apparently  by  some  friendly  arrange- 
ment,  succeeded  Dury  in  his  Abbacy,  as  well  as  in  the  office  of  Archdeacon  of  St. 
Andrews.  He  joined  the  party  of  the  Regent  Moray,  became  Secretary,  and  was 
much  trusted  and  employed  in  many  of  the  negotiations  of  that  distracted  period. 
In  1583,  he  was  denounced  rebel  for  his  share  in  the  raid  of  Ruthven,^  and  in  1585, 
Patrick,  Master  of  Gray,  had  a  Crown  grant  of  the  Abbacy,^  which,  on  his  disgrace 
in  1587,  was  granted  to  George  Earl  of  Huntlie.'* 

In  1593,  an  Act  of  Parliament  was  passed,  declaring  the  Abbacy  of  Dunferm- 
lin  perpetually  annexed  to  the  Orown  ;  and  another,  ratifying  the  gift  of  it  made  to 
the  Queeu  for  her  life  in  morowing-gift  at  Upslo  24th  November  1589.  In  1612, 
Parliament  ratified  an  infeftment  by  the  Sovereign,  of  date  7th  March  1 593,  on  the 
resignation  of  "  Henry  Pitcame  of  that  ilk,  as  commendator,"  to  the  Queen  and  her 
heirs,  with  all  infeftments  granted  by  her.' 

A  meagre  list  like  that  now  furnished,  of  tlie  Superiors  of  a  single  religious 
house,  will,  it  is  feared,  to  most  readers,  seem  equally  tedious  and  useless.  It  will 
be  aeceptable  to  the  few  who  have  groped  their  way  through  the  obscurer  periods  of 
Scotch  history,  without  the  guides  and  landmarks  which  are  fumished  for  such 
study  in  other  civilised  countries  ;  and  it  will  be  even  more  valued  by  the  explorer 
of  the  local  antiquities  of  the  district,  who,  in  the  confusion  of  a  pedigree  or  progress,

xviii  PREFACE. 

lias  often  longed  for  sometliing  to  fix  the  era  of  undated  charters  or  events  recorded 
only  in  connexion  with  the  Abbot  of  the  day.' 

Like  the  other  great  monasteries  of  Scotland,  Dunfemilin  acquired  the  great 
mass  of  its  property  at  a  very  early  period  of  its  history ;  and  the  acquisition  of  a 
considerable  portion  may  be  ascribed  to  the  period  immediately  succeeding  the 
restoration  of  Malcolm  III.,  when  the  national  convulsion,  and  the  defeat  of  the 
other  great  party,  placed  in  tlie  power  of  the  Crown  a  great  quantity  of  disposable 
property.-  In  these  possessions,  as  well  as  in  those  heaped  on  the  Abbey  by  David 
I.  and  his  successors,  so  far  as  they  consisted  in  landed  estates,  it  would  appear  that 
other  parties  soon  acquired  a  quasi  title  of  possession  under  tlie  Churoh.  Long 
before  feu-charters  were  granted,  and  probably  without  the  solemnity  of  any  written 
titles,  we  find  families  holding  extensive  lands  hereditarily  under  the  Abbot,  and 
vindicating  in  them  some  right  of  property.  Wheu  disputes  occurred,  the  Abbot,  who 
liad  not  only  the  keeping  but  the  framing  of  his  own  record,  had,  of  course,  the 
better ;  or  if  in  any  instances  he  was  unsuccessful,  such  events  were  not  likely  to 
find  a  place  in  this  Eegister. 

The  palpable  temptation  to  deceit  in  framing  their  Register,  and  the  opportu- 
nity  for  it  enjoyed  by  the  only  reading  and  writing  class  of  tlie  community,  lead  us 
to  examine  somewhat  critically,  the  records  by  which  a  great  house  like  Dunfermlin 
held  its  possessions.  13ut  this  is  really  a  more  serious  enquiry  to  a  Scotchman.  We 
have  here  a  great  Register  professing  to  record,  in  an  unbroken  series,  Papal  privi- 
leges,  Eoyal  charters,  and  the  deeds  of  Nobles  and  Princes,  from  the  beginning  of  the 
12th  century  down  to  the  Reformation,  and  reaching  back,  at  least  in  early  narra- 
tive,  to  transactions  of  the  llth  century.  Of  the  early  part  of  that  period,  no  other 
contemporary  records  exist,  except  sucli  grants  and  deeds  as  compose  this  Register. 
Therefore,  upon  their  authority  ultimately — by  the  style  of  these  writs — by  the 
incidental  information  aflbrded   by  them — hy  the  absence  of  all  reference  to  cusfoms. 


'  It  must  appear  strange  to  the  charter  scholar,  how  most  eamestly  towards  the  local  history  and  early 

histovical  antiquities  could  be  studied  at  aU,  before  the  statistics  of  his  native  county  of  Perth,  and  who  was 

industrious  Keith  published  his  lists  of  Bishops,  and  fully  aware  of  the  importance  of  tlie  monastic  records

as  frequent  a  witness  as  a  Bishop  ;  and  yet  nothing  labourer  may  be  allowed  to  deplore  that  his  taste  and 

has  been  done  to  coUect  the  chronological  aids  from         industry  should  have  left  so  few  memorials  : 

this  source.     Each  mariner  here  must  construct  his  Fkreet  vieminme  relictum  est. 

almanacks  and  tables  for  himself.    The  foundation  of  ^  The  charters  of  David  I.,  show  that,  of  the  lands 

the  above  list  of  the  Abbots  of  Dunfermlin,  was  laid  confirmed  by  him,  the  greater  part  flowed  from  the 

by  a  gentleman,  who,  in  his  zealous  study  of  Scotch  grants  of  his  father  and  brotherg. 
antiquities  and  history,  still  directed    his  attention 


PREFACE.  xix 

latci,  and  imtitutions.  which  must  kave  been  mentioned  if  theij  existed — must  be  settled 
some  of  those  great  questious  of  history  and  constitutional  law,  and  even  of  national 
independence,  which  havo  been  so  long  and  warmly  discussed  in  this  country.  /    > 

The  Ancient  Register  of  Dunfermlin  has  long  been  preserved  in  the  Advocates  %y  f\~'  l  '  O 
Library  at  Edinburgh.'  Though  recently  bound,  it  is  otherwise  in  precisely  the 
same  state  as  when  it  formed  the  subject  of  the  research  and  labour  of  the  first  Earl 
of  Haddington,^  more  than  two  centuries  ago.  That  careful  antiquary  has  left 
among  liis  collections^  a  minute  description  of  this  Eegister,  a  table  of  its  contents, 
both  of  which  have  been  used  for  the  present  work,*  and  a  great  body  of  extracts 
intended  to  throw  light  on  the  ancient  tenures  and  forms  of  conveyancing  of  Scotland. 

Like  all  Registers  of  this  kind,  the  MS.  is  of  very  different  ages.  In  trutli. 
the  ancient  Record  has  served  as  a  nucleus,  roimd  whieh  have  been  gathered  tlie 
successive  deeds  of  the  Monastery.  In  a  few  instances,  deeds  of  later  date  have 
been  interpolated  on  blank  pages  among  the  more  ancient  writs ;  but  these  are  easilv 
distinguishable  by  the  form  of  writing  as  well  as  the  substance.  Without  at  pre- 
sent  noticing  these  farther,  we  may  speak  of  what  Haddington  calls  "  The  Auld 
Registre,"  as  of  a  methodical  eonipilation,  and  though  not  always  placed  contiguouslv, 
forming  a  definite  portion  of  the  volume. 

It  is  arranged  under  heads  ; — Charters  of  the  Kings  from  David  to  Alex.  III. ^'^ 
the  Bishops  of  Saint  Andrews"  and  Dunkeld;''  the  Chapter  of  St.  Andrews  ;*  the 
Earls  of  Fife^  and  Athol ;'"  Countesses  Ada  and  Ela;"  Charters  of  Laymen;''* 
Covenants  and  conventions  regarding  disputed  territories  ;''  and  BuUs  of  Popes.'''  The 
haud  writing  of  the  greater  part  of  the  Record  now  described,  may  be  ascribed,  without 
much  doubt,  to  the  reign  of  Alexander  II.  or  the  early  half  of  the  ISth  centurv.

XX  PREFACE. 

As  far  as  tliat  reign,  the  leading  part — the  record  of  Eoyal  Charters — is  uniforni. 
and  apparently  the  work  of  one  scribe.  With  the  reign  of  Alexander  III.  begins 
a  difterent  hand  and  far  less  careful  form  of  registering.  There  is  no  longer  the 
methodical  cLassification  of  deeds,  nor  the  rubricated  titles  and  ornamented  initial 
letters.  We  find  few  deeds  of  the  period  of  the  troubles  that  followed  the  death  of 
Alexander  III. ;  and  if  it  may  be  allowed  to  conjecture,  there  was  probably  no 
registering  during  that  disturbed  time.  When  order  was  restored  under  Eobert, 
the  Eecord  has  been  again  brought  into  use,  and  the  entries  of  deeds  of  that  period 
and  subsequently,  appear  to  have  been  made  soon  after  the  date  of  each  writ ; — 
not,  however,  in  any  regular  classification,  and  mixed  frequently  with  others  of  a 
niuch  niore  ancient  date,  registered  at  the  same  time  and  in  the  same  hand, 
undisguisedly. 

It  will  be  observed,  the  Chartulary  goes  no  farther  back  than  the  remodelHng 
of  the  Monastery  by  David  I.  The  oarlier  part,  which  alone  is  likely  to  be  called 
in  question,  must  have  been  written  in  the  time  of  his  great-grandson,  if  not  even 
sooner ;  and  it  happeus  singularly  that  the  leading  Charter  of  each  reign  so  fits  into 
that  of  the  preceding,  that  a  fraud  is  reudered  impossible,  unless  we  suppose  it 
perpetrated  by  the  Sovereign  or  his  Chancellor. 

Our  Eegister  does  not  lose  in  authority  by  an  omission  wliich  must  now  be 
mentioned.  In  the  second  volume  of  the  Blonasticon,  Dugdale  has  printed  a  deed 
purporting  to  be  the  foundation  charter  of  Dunfermlin  by  Maleolm  III.,  on  the 
authority  of  Sir  James  Balfour,  who  then  stood  higli  in  estimation.  We  have  been 
able  to  trace  this  to  the  copy  in  Balfour's  own  hand ;'  but  nowhere  is  any  indication 
u-iven  of  the  source  from  which  he  copied  it.  He  uses  indeed  the  phrase,  concordut 
cum  autographo  ;  but  that  must  not  go  for  much  with  those  who  know  the  "  Lyone." 
His  inaccuracy,  for  one  at  all  addicted  to  historical  investigation,  is  beyond  all 
example.  The  Charter,  however,  has  been  received  and  copied  by  succeeding  anti- 
quaries,^  who  have  endeavoured  to  reconcile  it  with  history  with  indiflerent  success. 

'  MS.  Adv.  Lihr.,  33. 2.  5.     ( W.  2.  29.)     This  vol-  great  work  ;  and  it  was  presented  by  Miss  Fairfa.x  of 

ume  which  contains  copies,  in  Balfour's  own  hand,  Stretton  to  Bishop  Keith  in  1754,  who  at  his  deiith

scarcely  be  sustained ;  and  with  it  Falls  all  proof  of  written  title  or  of  writing  being

The  Register  of  Dunfermlin  stands  ou  a  better  foundation ;  and  indeed  no 
record  is  throughout  freer  from  suspicion.  The  antiquity  of  the  liandwriting,  and 
regularity  of  its  early  part,  are  certainly  calculated  to  give  it  great  authority.  Eut 
it  is  not  wantLng  in  other  supports.  In  the  volume  of  original  Bulls  collected  by  Sir

that  came  into  dispute.  The  Earls  and  Barons  are 
too  ostentatiously  put  forward,  at  a  time  when  it 
may  be  doubted  if  their  respective  ranks  were  quite

crossof  subscription.  But  here  there  is  not  one  Bishop.

xxii  PREFACE. 

faithfulness  and  accuracy  of  the  framers  of  the  Register.  When  we  add  to  this  the 
unusual  linking  on,  of  the  great  charters  of  the  successive  kings  after  David  I.,  each 
confirming  the  very  terms  of  his  predecessor's  grant ;  and  the  historical  fact,  that 
under  these  charters,  the  Abbey  possessed  its  vast  estates  for  many  centuries,  and 
down  to  a  period  quite  withiu  the  reach  of  history — it  seems  really  that  no  record 
of  any  antiquity  is  established  by  a  greater  body  of  intrinsic  and  extrinsic  evidence. 
It  is  not  of  mere  wantonness  that  these  proofs  of  tlie  authenticity  of  this  Register 
are  arrayed,  but  cliiefly  from  tlie  importance  that  has  been  attached  to  the  style  in 
which  the  leading  charters  of  David  I.  and  his  successors  run.  "  In  nomine  sancte 
et  indifidue  trinitatis,  Ego  Dauid  Dei  gratia  Rex  Scottorum,  atictoritate  regia  ac 
potestate ;  E^yiscoporum,  Comitum  Baronumque  regni  mei  confirmatione  et  testimonio  ; 
Clero  efiam  adqtiiescente  et  Popido  ,•" — these  are  very  formal  ternis  of  sanction,  and  to 
a  mind  predisposed  to  admit  the  theory,  readily  take  the  shape  of  a  solemn  legisla- 
tive  enactment,  by  the  authority  of  the  King^s  most  excellent  majesty,  by  and  with 
the  advice  and  consent  of  the  Lords  Spiritual  and  Temporal  and  Commons  in  Par- 
liament  assembled.'  So  reasonable  did  the  inference  appear,  and  yet  so  adverse  to 
the  sound  view  of  the  introduetion  of  our  parliamentary  constitution,  that  later  en- 
quirers  have  solved  the  difficulty  by  denying  the  autliority  of  the  charters  founded 
on.  The  palpable  objections  to  the  pretended  foundation  charter  of  Malcolm  have 
been  extended  to  the  whole  ;  and  the  most  authentic  and  venerable  of  our  Scotch 
records  has  been  brought  into  question.  After  all,  it  is  a  mere  delusion.  There  is 
no  mention  of  parliament  or  general  council  in  tliese  charters ;  no  assertion  of  the 
"  parliamentary  powers  of  the  people;"  no  way  has  been  devised  in  which  they 
could  yet  express  their  consent  as  one  of  the  three  estates.  If  it  be  regarded  with- 
out  prepossession,  the  preamble  of  these  writs  only  sets  forth  in  affected  and  monkish 
magniloquence,  that  theRoyal  munificeneewas  bestowedwith  the  general  approbationof 
the  country.  If  the  evidence  were  much  more  in  point,  it  is  dangerous  to  build  theories 
of  constitution  on  a  single  writ;  but,  unwarned  by  the  rashness  of  their  predecessors,  we 
have  the  same  error  committed  even  in  the  present  day,  and  by  historical  antiquaries 
of  more  research  and  much  higher  name  than  the  speculator  who,  out  of  an  apo- 
cryphal  charter,  constructed  a  perfect  Scotch  Parliament  in  the  reign  of  Malcohn 
Canmore.^

PREFACE.  xxiii 

It  is  necessary  briefly  to  explain  the  arrangement  of  tlie  present  volumu. — Tln 
first  189  pages  contain  what  may  bo  most  correctly  styled  the  Ancient  Register,  begini 
probably  early  iu  Alexander  II. ''s  reign,  and  brought  down  nearly  to  the  end  of  that 
of  his  son.  FoUowing  the  arrangeinent  of  the  original,  it  is  divided  under  the  heads 
of  the  different  classes  of  granters.  In  the  class  of  Crown  grants,'  the  only  liberty 
used  is  in  placing  the  great  confirmatory  charter  of  eacli  reign  at  its  commencement, 
which  is  not  always  the  case  in  the  Record,  though  it  does  not  pretend  to  place  them 
chronologically.  The  charters  of  the  Bishops^  have  been  only  so  far  altered  in  ar- 
rangement  as  to  place  tlie  successive  Bishops  in  right  order  of  succession.  In  the 
section  of  charters  of  layraen,^  the  order  of  the  origiual  has  been  adhered  to  ;  but  the 
bulls  of  the  Popes,''  where  ascertainable  with  certainty,  have  been  occasionally  altered 
in  position  to  suit  chronology. 

The  remaiuder  of  the  Register,^  including  charters  interpolated  on  the  leaves  of 
the  most  ancient  part,  has  been  arranged,  not  with  reference  to  the  supposed  period 
of  registration,  but  in  conformity  with  the  actual  or  conjectural  date  of  the  various 
instruments.  Those  of  lowest  dates,  least  importance,  and  greatest  bulk,  have  been 
abridged  at  the  eud."  It  has  been  endeavoured  to  preserve  in  every  case  the  exact 
operative  terms  of  the  original,  and  all  clauses  and  even  expressions  unusual  or 
otherwise  interesting,  as  well  as  the  names  of  the  witnesses,  where  these  were  other 
than  the  members  of  the  convent. 

In  every  book  of  register  like  tlie  present,  are  fouud  wi-its  uudated,  and  evi- 
dently  designed  as  styles.  These  have  been  collected,  and  are  here  placed  at  the 
conclusion  of  the  Abbreviates  ;'  and  lastly,  nine  entries,  omitted  in  arranging  the 
work  for  the  press,  are  subjoined." 

The  only  remaining  matter  of  the  vohime,  known  under  the  name  of  the  Char- 
tulary  of  Dunfermlyn,  is  a  "  tabill"  of  some  antiquity,  referring  to  the  contents  of 
the  volume  before  its  more  recent  additions  at  the  begiuning  and  end.     This  has 

from  the  publication  of  a  great  body  of  Scotch  diplo-  should  be  found  to  a  court  of  paramount  authority,like 

macy,  that  antiquaries  shall  no  longer  be  at  liberty  to  the  curiu  septem  comitum  Scotie — if  such  a  court  ever

been  prefixed  to  tlie  present  work,  and  witli  the  help  of  tables  of  the  Earl  of 
Haddington,  applicable  to  the  more  raodern  matter,  has  been  made  to  serve  the  pur- 
pose  both  of  a  reference  to  the  original,  and  a  table  of  the  contents  of  the  printed 
volume. 

The  contents  of  the  first  Appendix,  consisting  of  the  Apocryphal  charter  of 
Malcolm  III.'  and  of  nine  bulls  and  charters,^  printed  from  the  originals  in  the 
Advocates'  Library,  have  been  already  referred  to. 

The  Second  Appendix,  the  Rental  of  tlie  Abbacy,  as  taken  iip  in  1561  and  suc- 
cessive  years,  under  the  Act  appropriating  the  thirds  of  benefices  to  the  ministers  of 
religion  and  to  the  Crown,  is  printed  from  a  vohime  of  Lord  Haddington's  Collec- 
tions  in  the  sarae  Library.^  '    ' 

The  Third  Appendix  gives  the  contents  of  five  volumes  of  feu-rights  and  other 
charters  and  leases  granted  by  the  successive  Abbots  or  Commendators  of  Dunferm- 
lin,  of  the  property  belonging  to,  or  held  under  their  House  ;  and  by  Queen  Anne  of 
Denmark,  "  Ladie  of  Dunferraelyn."  The  first  of  these*  is  now  in  the  possession  of  the 
Marquess  of  Tweeddale,  the  heritable  Baillie  of  the  Eegality  of  Dunfermlin.  On  its 
first  leaf  it  bears  the  following  inscription ; — Notum  rentale  seu  registrum  terrarum 
ad  Regalitateni  de  Dunfermling  spectantium  anno  millesimo  quingentesimo  quinqua- 

gesimo  quinto  per  dominum  Joannem monachum  professum  ejusdem  de  man- 

dato  Reverendi  [viri'}  Georgii  Durie  commendatarii  [_dicti'\  monasterii  .  I .  Henrisone 
chartarius.,  notarius  puhlicus.  The  inventory  of  its  contents  is  from  Haddington^s 
Collections,^  collated  with  the  original  volume.  The  second  volume^  is  not  now 
known  to  exist.  The  inventorj'  of  its  contents  is  copied  from  Lord  Haddington. 
The  third,''  of  which  the  contents  are  also  described  from  Lord  Haddington's  inven- 
tory,  is  now  in  the  General  Register  House,  and  it  has  been  collated  for  this  work. 
The  inventories  of  the  contents  of  the  fourth  volume,"  which  is  in  the  possession  of 
tlie  Marquess  of  Tweeddale,  and  of  the  fifth,^  which  is  preserved  in  the  Advocates 
Library,  are  not  contained  in  Lord  Haddington's  collections,  but  have  been  raade 
up  from  the  originals. 

As  a  body  of  ancient  statistical  and  local  information,  it  is  hoped  this  volume 
raay  be  found  even  richer  than  any  of  the  former  published  chartularies.  These 
records  are  graduaUy  extending  over  Scotland  a  net-work  of  local  and  charter  historj^ 
which  will  save  us  in  future  from  ignorant  guessers,  and  lay  a  foundation  for  that 

'  MSS.  Adv.  Libr.,  32,  2.  5.     (  W.  2.  29.)  ^  Msg.  Jdv.  Libr.,  34.  2.  1,     (A.  4.  IB.)

PREFACE.  XXV 

wliieh  tlic  civilizatiDii  of  thc  couutry  demands, — a  hiistur}'  of  tho  early  settlement 
and  transmission  of  land  in  each  district.  Such  an  object  niight  be  well  joined  to 
the  study  of  Family  history.  It  is  of  iufinitely  greater  utility,  and  there  is  no 
reason  why  somewhat  of  the  same  interest  that  is  felt  in  a  long-descended  pedigree 
of  a  noble  name,  should  not  attach  to  a  well  proved  descent  of  lands. 

To  trace  the  history  of  the  buildings  of  the  united  Church,  Monastery,  and 
Palace  of  Dunfermlin,  would  exceed  the  bounds  of  a  prefatory  notice,  and  could 
not  be  satisfactory  or  intelligible  witliout  aid  from  drawings.  The  original  Churcli 
of  Canmore,  perhaps  not  of  stone,  niust  have  been  replaced  by  a  new  edifice  when  it 
was  dedicated  in  the  reign  of  David  I.'  If  any  part  of  that  structure  reniain,  it 
must  be  little  more  than  the  foundations.  Age,  or  the  accidents  of  a  rough  time,  or 
the  increasing  consequence  of  the  House,  gave  rise  to  an  enlarged  and  more  magnifi- 
cent  structure^  about  the  middle  of  the  l.Sth  century.  The  translation  of  the  Saintlv 
foundress  was  probably  arranged  to  give  solemnity  to  the  opening  of  the  New  Church. 
Soon  after  that,  Dunfermliu  is  described  by  one  who  was  probably  an  eye-witucss  of 
what  he  tells,^  as  of  vast  extent,  inclosing  three  plough-lands  within  its  precincts, 
and  containiug  palaces  of  such  niagnificence,  that  three  kings,  with  their  trains, 
might  be  accommodated  in  it  at  once  without  inconvenience.  This  sumptuous  pile 
was  destroyed  and  levelled  with  the  ground,  by  the  soldiers  of  Edward  in  1.30:5, 
oxcepting  only  the  Church  and  a  few  dwellings  for  the  monks. 

The  accounts  of  the  Great  Chamberlains  give  us  some  notiees  of  the  expensive 
funerals  and  tomb  of  Robert  Bruce  at  Dunfermlin.  So  entirely  liad  the  Hero's 
tonib  disappeared,  that  its  situation  was  lately  discovered  rather  by  accident  than 
liistorical  deduction.     Even  local  tradition  afForded  no  assistance. 

On  the  28th  March,  1561,  the  Lords  of  the  Congregation  "  past  to  Stirling, 
and  be  the  way  kest  doun  the  Abbey  of  Dunfermling."'' 

The  Nave  of  the  Church  of  the  thirteenth  century  remains  pretty  entire — a 
valuable  specimen  of  the  architecture  of  that  age.  The  Choir  has  been  taken  awav 
and  replaced  by  a  modern  Church.  The  tombs  and  remaius  of  the  Kings  and  Saints 
vvhich  lie  crowded  round  that  old  High  Altar,  are  now  unknown  and  dishonoured. 

I  Anno  1150.     Cliron.  S.  Ci-mis.  from  all  but  the  usual  procurations,  due  at  all  Epis- 

"  Ecclesia  per  noUlioris  struclure  fibricam  fuerit  uug-  copal  visitations.    And  only  two  days  later,  His  Holi-

xxvi  PREFACE. 

Even  the  grave  of  Robert  tlie  Bruce,  which  was  lately  opeued,  is  iiot  distiuguished 
iu  any  way,  except  that  it  is  said  to  lie  below  a  vulgar  modern  pulpit. 

Of  the  Cloisters  uothing  remains.  The  oldest  remaining  part  of  tlie  Palace  is 
not  of  higher  antiquity  (uuless  perliaps  the  mere  foundations)  than  the  1.5tli  centurv. 
The  greater  part  of  the  picturesque  ruins  is  more  modern.  The  Palace  must  liave 
been  still  habitable  on  the  19th  of  November  1600,  when  Charles  I.  was  born  there. 

It  was  fit  that  after  five  ceuturies,  the  last  princely  deseendant  to  be  born  in 
Scotland  of  the  marriage  of  Malcolm  and  Saiut  Margaret,  who  was  to  bear  to  the 
Auglo-Saxon  throne,  the  blood  of  the  Confessor,  and  the  misfortunes  of  all  his  race, 
should  first  see  the  light  within  the  old  walls  of  Dunfermliu.

[NoTA. — Before  and  efter  this  tabill  ther  is  xxxiiij  leatis  of  parchment  Uaddingon'/  Coi. 
of  new  vryt.     The  tabill  occupyis  four  leafs  and  8  lyins  and  syne  the

In  the  buik  with  the  auld  trie  brodes 

Thair  is  first  xxxiiij  leiffis  of  pairchment.  On  the  foreside  of  thc  tirst  leiff  and  four 
Ivnes  on  the  baksyd  js  writtin  in  text  hand  twa  collectis  in  latein.  And  tlien  benethe 
on  the  baksyde  of  the  first  leife  is  writtin  the  forme  of  a  commission  to  replege  out 
of  the  iustice  aires.     [N.  588.] 

And  ane  forme  of  aue  Attornay  out  of  the  chancellarie.     fol.  1.     [N.  589.]

Tak  ye  same  furth  of  Kirkcaldie 

At  Leith  the  xviii  day  of  Januare  1571  • 

The  Commissionaris  of  ye  kirk  for  certane  ressonable  caussis  and  consideratiounes 
moveing  thame  Ordeanes  thare  collectour  and  clerk  ouer  the  rentallis  to  exehange 
of  yair  assumptioune  of  ye  beire  of  ye  abbay  of  Dumfermling  vj  .  cli .  viij  .  b  .  beir 
quhilk  wes  takin  out  of  befoir  of  ye  parochin  of  Kinglassie  To  be  now  takin  out  of 
ye  ferme  beir  of  ye  nedder  grange  of  Kinghorne  geveand  be  zeir  vj  .  ch  .  And  of  ye 
dry  multouris  of  wester  Kinghorne  geveand  be  zeir  viij  .  b  .  And  sua  Kinglassie  quhilk 
payit  in  the  Kirkis  assumptioune  of  befoir  x  .  ch  .  ij  .  b  .  j  .  f .  sall  now  pay  bot  iij  .  ch  . 
X  .  b  .  j  .  pc  .  and  the  remanent  of  ye  beir  quhilk  wes  assumeit  out  of  Kinglassie  of 
befoir  extending  to  ye  saidis  vj  .  ch  .  viij  .  b  .  to  be  now  tane  out  of  wester  Kinghorne 
and  dry  multeris  befoir  specifeit  Makand  in  the  haill  x  .  ch  .  ij  .  b  .  i .  p  .  quhilk 
wes  tane  haillalie  of  Kinglassie  of  befoir  Provyding  alwayis  give  ye  Kirk  findis  thame 
selffis  hurt  be  this  exchange  throw  evill  pay'  or  wtherwayis  that  thay  and  thair  col- 
lectour  sall  hawe  recours  agane  to  thair  awld  assumptioun  or  ells  the  eommendatour 
of  Dumfermhng  sall  assigne  tharae  better  pay'  at  yair  optioun  quhil  yai  find  thame 
selffis  in  als  guid  cais  as  thay  wer  be  thair  awld  assumptioun  .  Sic  subscribiture 
R.  Dumfermeling  M'.  Jolme  wynrame  Jo"  Erskene  .
